This document has a restricted distribution and may be used by recipients only in the performance o f their official duties. Its contents may not be otherwise disclosed without World Bank authorization.   A. BACKGROUNDAND STRATEGY
1. Background
Lebanon's electricity sector suffers from years o f overall poor governance, weak institutional, management and technical capacity, and a serious lack of investment in operation and maintenance as well as new infrastructure. This has ledto poor quality o f service, low consumer confidence in public service provision, high cost o f electricity and inadequate cost-recovery. The main consequences are a considerable dependence of the sector on budgetary subsidies estimated by the Ministry o f Finance to be close to US$1 billion in 2006 and high additional costs born by users, particularly industries, to compensate for the unreliability o f power supply. This situationis expected to further deteriorate unless drastic actions are taken soon.
The problems date back to the end o f the 1975-1990 civil war, when Electricit6 du Liban (EdL) struggled, without success, to resume reliable and affordable electricity services throughout Lebanon. The main outstanding issues can be summarized as follows:
The cost o f electricity generation i s high because o f lack of access to natural gas for power generation. Out o f Lebanon's four main generation plants, two plants were originally designed and built to operate on natural gas but instead run on very expensive gas oil. The two other main plants (Jiyeh and Zouk) have long passed their refurbishing time and have high generation cost and use imported fuel oil which is subject to high international oil prices; The system operation is inefficient. Plant efficiency is below normal levels due to poor maintenance, poor control o f fuel stocks and consumption, and an ad hoc dispatch to meet demand; The reliability o f supply is poor. The transmission network is fraught with problems. The main 220kV backbone grid i s not yet fully completed, nor i s the long-planned national load control center inplace. Major investments are also requiredinthe medium- and low-voltage transmission and distribution systems as well as in metering to reduce transmission and distribution losses. But EdL's worsening deficiency inmanagerial and technical capacity, as well as poor planning and execution o f funding have long delayed implementation o f investmentprograms; Metering, billing and collection are highly inefficient. Technical losses are estimated at about 15%, while another 17.8% loss i s explained by illegal connections. In reality, out o f the 67% o f the power produced that EdL manages to bill for, about 90% on average i s eventually collected annually; EdL's management systems are outdated and ineffective. Accounting and financial reporting systems are not functioning adequately and do not allow the annual closing o f EdL's account or their auditing. The consumer management system i s not reliable while the human resources management system i s also ineffective.
The serious technical deficiencies in the sector are closely related to the poor governance o f the sector and the lack o f implementation o f much needed reforms o f EdL. Indeed, a major problem i s the legal status o f EdL as a non-commercial "Etablissement Public", which puts EdL's staff under the status of civil servants, with an inadequate pay scale to retain competent managers and
1  technical staff and career management rules incompatible with the operation o f a utility. EdL's staff i s about 57 years old on average and EdL i s currently losing around 150 staff per year to retirement out o f about 2,300 current employees. This is further aggravated by the lack o f a sector strategy and o f a long term investment plan to orient investment decisions based on economic and technical criteria and to ensure that investment decisions are made in a timely manner. Finally, the vicious circle o f lack o f financing due to the socio-political difficulty to charge cost reflective tariffs, leading to lack o f investment and poor service, which in turn encourages power thefts and poor payment discipline, results in a widening financial gap. This gap i s very vulnerable to changes in international oil prices as Lebanon imports all o f its energy needs.
Right before the hostilities broke out the situation with EdL had reached a critical point, including a complete dearth o f human resources to manage operations and address financial and administrative problems, a surge in sector deficits which had to be met through treasury advances for fuel payments and debt service (from about US$275 million in 2003 to a total burdeno f about US$570 million in 2005, and up to US$1billion in 2006; the latest figure was heavily impacts by the high oil prices in 2006), and an all time low confidence in the sector by the electricity consumers who due to lack o f electricity availability and frequent power cuts equip themselves with costly back-up generators. This situation was further aggravated by the adverse impact of the recent high prices o f crude oil, on which Lebanon relies heavily for its power generation. The high pricing policy, along with the unreliable supply i s a major problem for the industrial development in Lebanon, and thus a barrier to the country's overall economic growth. Furthermore, low income consumers who cannot afford runningtheir own generator are fully exposed to the effect o fun-reliablepower supply.
The negative cumulative effect o f the inefficient situation had become impossible to ignore and on July 6, 2006 the Council o f Ministers approved a reform program aimed at addressing the most critical problems and achieving the quickest improvements possible. However, on July 13, the hostilities broke out and, once again an electricity sector reform program was put to the side as more urgentpriorities took over.
2. Impact of the July 2006 Hostilities
The hostilities lasted for 33 days. On August 14, 2006, a UN-brokered ceasefire brought an end to the intense hostilities. The hostilities resulted in serious human and physical infrastructure losses in Lebanon. The direct damage has been estimated by the World Bank at about US$2.4 billion with a further $700-$800 million o f indirect damage. The cost o f the hostilities as well as the social impact on the lives and livelihoods o f the families affected also dealt a severe blow to Lebanon's long-term prospects for recovery. Economy-wide losses o f revenue from foregone output are estimated at US$2.3 billion in 2006 alone and the projected growth in real GDP o f 6 percent in 2006 has contracted by nearly the same magnitude. Jobs have been lost, government revenues have dropped while at the same time government expenditures have increased by approximately US$690 million`.

2  Although the hostilities caused limited direct physical harm to the overall electricity infrastructure (the physical damage has been estimated at US$84 million), the indirect impact i s substantial.
The latter includes: (i) The loss o f revenue (primarily due to a drop in supply capacity, interruptions in collections innumerous areas, and the destruction o f some service perimeters); and (ii) The increased cost o f generation for EdL (primarily due to damage to the production fuel supply chain, particularly storage facilities).
In turn, these indirect effects have severely aggravated the short term needs for government subsidiesto the power sector.
Moreover, the unexpected and substantial increase in public expenditures needed for the country's reconstruction efforts in other sector which suffered more extensive damage put a tremendous burden on the government's finances and make government subsidies to the power sector even more un-sustainable than before the hostilities. And last, Lebanon will be under increasing pressure from donors as a condition for their support to show its concrete commitment to urgently address the severe performance problems, inefficiencies and poor governance o f the power sector. It i s against this grim public finance context that swift action on the reform o f the power sector no longer i s a choice but a must.
3. Government Strategy
In2002, an Electricity Law (Law 462) was passedwhich lays out the restructuring o f EdL. The Law calls for the creation o f a regulatory authority, unbundling o f all or parts o f the sector, incorporation o f the new entities under commercial law, and, ultimately, privatization o f up to 40% o f the shares. Since the Law was enacted, several attempts have been made to advance its implementationbut there has beenno change to the structure or status o f EdL as o f yet.
The July 2006 reform package includes immediate reforms and initiatives for improving sector performance. That reform program has as ultimate objective to turn the sector around through private sector participation, in accordance with Law 462. While there is recognition that full privatization would be difficult intoday's environment o f significant dependence o f the sector on large subsidies and o f high political risk, several steps have been proposed to commence the turnaround o f the sector, including restructuring and incorporation under commercial law and outsourcingto the private sector o f key functions. The key objectives o f the government's power sector reform are to:
(i) Reduce the government subsidiesto the sector; (ii) Ensure continuous supply o f quality electricity and restore consumer confidence in the sector; (iii) Make the sector commercially viable through lowering the cost o f electricity production, develop a priority investment program, including completion o f priority projects such as introduction o f natural gas and feasibility studies for generation capacity;
3  (iv) Improve governance and management by establishing systems and processes to' enable the generation o f reports with reliable information (financial and technical); and (v) Develop a comprehensive privatization strategy which is commensurate with the risks inLebanon. More specifically, the reform package endorsed by the GOLprovides for:
Better governance

Cost reduction The contracting o f an international consultant to supervise the operation and maintenance contracts for the Zahrani and Baddawi power plants; The contracting o f an international consultant to assess the validity o f retaining the Zouk and Jiyehpower plants untilmore efficient substituteplants are constructed;
0 The extension o f the natural gas pipeline from the Baddawi area to the Zahrani area, and its phased implementation;
Improved quality of sewice
0 The contracting an international consultant to invite private investments in new power plants inthe Baddawi, Zahrani and other geographical areas through Independent Power Producers; and,
0 The signing o f a contract with consultants C.R.A. International to complete the re- engineering of the distribution segment in order to improve billing, metering and cost recovery o f EdL.
The reform program i s attached ina matrix format inAnnex 2.
The urgency o f the Government's reforms, including the reform measures relating to the power sector, has been confirmed and validated at the January 25, 2007, Paris I11Conference, during which the international community was presented with the Government's comprehensive and ambitious reform program and asked to provide its financial support. The substantial aid pledgedto Lebanon (over US$ 7.6 billion) and the repeated emphasis put on acting on the power sector were testimonies o f the collective recognition o f the priority need to address the power sector situation as part o f the country's sustainable reconstruction and economic recovery program. The proposedproject will lay the necessary institutional foundation for the recovery o f the power sector and to meet the Government stated priorities listed above.
4  B. BANK RESPONSEAND STRATEGY
Bank Response. On September 20, 2006, the Bank's Board o f Governors approved a transfer o f US$70 million from IBRD surplus to a Trust Fund for Lebanon (TFL) (Resolution 580) to support the Government's reconstruction efforts. Bank support centers on priority areas where the Bank has a distinct comparative advantage, namely the rehabilitation o f damaged infrastructure, support to groups affected by the hostilities andjump-starting economic activities.
The Bank's short-term emergency response to the post-hostilities needs centered on undertaking an economic and social impact assessment (ESIA) which outlines key reform elements necessary for transitioning from short-term reconstructionto sustainable growth.
Bank Strategy. The ESIA includes a comprehensive chapter on the electricity sector. In this chapter, the Bank provides recommendations for the power sector in the short- and medium- term. The key strategic points are highlighted below:
Major efforts are needed to improve governance. Areas where improvement i s particularly critical are billing and collection, management o f the fuel chain and investment decision making; Improved commercial operation o f EdL through incorporation will contribute to both reducing the fiscal burden on Government through improved productivity and management and improving service delivery through better planning, more focus on operation and maintenance (O&M) o f facilities and the possibility to hire competent and skilled staff at market salaries. The sector investment needs are very significant, but can only be economic and efficient if two conditions are in place: (i) management and skills at EdL; and (ii)proper least better a cost expansion plan i s undertaken, along with an assessment o f the transmission and distribution investment needs. This needs to be accompanied by a comprehensive fuel sourcing strategy. Lessons from the reconstruction after the civil war have shown that long-term environmental impacts from hasty reconstruction can offset benefits if proper mitigating measures are not implementedina timely manner. Hence the sector reform and reconstruction process should be consistent with a proper environmental protection strategy.
The recommendations o f the World Bank are fully consistent and supportive o f the Government's reform program inthe sector.
Rationalefor Bank involvement. The proposed project i s a key pillar o f the Bank's assistance to Lebanon following the hostilities. The project will assist in addressing the performance problems o f the sector which inturn will, over the mediumterm, reduce the fiscal burdeno f the sector and thus free up government resources for other priority uses. This i s particularly acute given the contraction o f the economy as well as the increased expenditure to rebuild housing, basic infrastructure andprovide assistance to those most affected by the hostilities.
The Bank and Lebanon have a long-standingrelationship inthe energy sector, both ininvestment support and sector reform. There have been several projects, but with mixed results on the
5  policy and reform front. Since the end o f the hostilities last summer, the Bank has been working closely with the government at all levels and across several ministries to lay out the reform program for the sector, which has also served as the basis on which Lebanon has sought substantial donor support. Most o f the emphasis has been placed on the short-term measures that will initiate the reform process and establish sound foundations for sustainable sector recovery over the longer term.
The rationale for Bank involvement is therefore the extensive experience that the Bank brings in terms o f implementing sector reform in difficult settings, which help lay sound foundations for sustainable growth over the medium to longer term. The proposed grant project may followed by IBRD support, which in turn would help provide the policy environment under which significant other donors' funds can contribute to meet the significant investment and institutional needs inthe sector.

3. Lessonslearnedand reflectedin the projectdesign
The Bank's past experience o f the implementation o f sector reform projects in Lebanon shows mixed results. Reforms have been slow to be designed and endorsed, partially due to the political fragmentation o f the country and interference in the day to day operations o f EdL. However, the momentum for reform i s high in Lebanon at the moment, given the heavy burden
8  the sector places on the government budget and the need for the government to fund other priority reconstruction efforts. Therefore, the sector reform plan agreed among the key decision- makers i s worth supporting. The most important first ingredient i s to ensure sufficient capacity to implementwhat has been endorsed and work out the details o fhow to restructure EdL
The Bank's experience in implementing projects in post-conflict countries has highlighted the importance o f a synergy-focused, flexible and very concrete project design to allow for adaptation to changing circumstances in a context o f wide participation o f the donor community. In line with this, the project design has been kept concrete, supporting the implementation of measures that already emerged from earlier work in the sector. Laying the ground for sector reform will also lead to increased opportunities for donors to provide further financing support to this longer-term initiative and the associated investmentneeds.
Over the years, the Bank has also captured global lessons on power sector reform. The main lessons learned that are relevant for Lebanon are:
Incash short sectors, it is vital to have strong, centralizedcash management inplace before unbundling to ensure money will flow back to fuel procurement and O&M, otherwise subsidies may increase; Unbundling should be done carefully and the number o f unbundled entities should be as limitedas possible; Learn how to reform as the process gets underway - be ready to make adjustments midstream; Ensurethere is sufficient in-house capacityto design and manage the reformprocess.
D. INSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTSAND PROJECTIMPLEMENTATION
1. Institutionalandimplementationarrangements
The project will be implemented over a period o f two years, using existing Government structures where possible. The institutional arid implementation arrangements will be as follows:
The three assignments will be overseen by an inter-ministry Higher Level Committee (HLC) under the chairmanship o f the Prime Minister and comprising the Ministers o f Energy and Finance, the Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR), the Higher Council for Privatization (HCP) and EdL. While the implementingagency will be the CDR which will also sign the contracts, the beneficiaries o f the grant are MOEW, EdL and the HCP, acting as an administrator o f the H L C for the restructuring o f EdL. A Project Agreement will be enteredinto between the CDR and the World Bank. The selection and evaluation committee for the consulting assignments will be headed by the CDR and comprise representatives from the H L C (Le., the Prime Minister's Office, CDR, HCP, MOEW, MOF and EdL). The consultants will report directly to the beneficiaries and to the H L C as needed. The beneficiaries will coordinate with the CDR for payment processing purposes.
9  2. Monitoringand evaluationof outcomes/results
The CDR will provide quarterly progress reports that monitor the progress o f the technical assistance financed under the project. Inaddition, these progress reports will serve as a basis for optimizing the coordination efforts between the three components o f the project. These reports will be submittedto the World Bank, the MOEW, the CDR andthe HCP.
Given the high level o f complexity and sensitivity o f the issues addressed under this project, strong supervision efforts, including frequent field visits, will be needed, particularly at key junctures o f the restructuring o fEdL.
3. Procurementarrangements
The Grant is intendedto fund three (3) contracts for consultant services to be provided by firms, all to be recruited in compliance with the Bank Guidelines. It i s estimated that those contracts will cost US$8 million equivalent of which the Grant will finance US$5 million. The procurement methods for the consulting firms and the level o f Bank review are established inthe project's procurement plan designed by CDR during appraisal and to be updated on a quarterly basis or when needed. All updates will be submittedfor Bank's approval.
The grant will be implementedby CDR which has extensive experience inhandlingprocurement following Bank Guidelines. Substantial lessons have been learned over the years in expediting administrative procedures, and the inherent risk i s therefore foreseen to be average with respect to procurement processing. The Planning and Programming Division will implement the project and the Director o f this Division will take the role o f Project Coordinator for this project. H e will be assisted by a team o f engineers with previous World Bank project experience and the Selection and Evaluation Committee duringthe consultant selection and evaluation phases. The Division will be responsible for monitoring and managing ongoing contracts.
Each o f the three beneficiaries o f the program (MOEW, EdL, and the Higher Level Committee) will assign staff for managing the project. This staff will follow up on procurement processing: (i)validate TORS,(ii)participate inthe selection ofthe respective consultant and contract negotiation, and (iii) monitor the consultant and manage the contracts. Payments from CDR will be issued upon submission o f the request from the pertinentbeneficiary attaching an approval o f the consultant's invoice. A copy o fthe submittedreports shall be filed inCDR.
The Planning and Programming Division will be responsible for maintaining accurate procurement records, including all actions related to Bank-financed procurement. This includes advertisement, all submitted expressions o f interest and proposals, minutes o f public openings, evaluation process, contract administration, deliverables and reports, invoices and payment copies. The procurement files and updated procurement plans will be maintained for review by the Bank's supervisionmissions. The beneficiaries will maintain complete filing with respect to contract administration: contract copy, deliverables and reports, invoices copy, payment copy, etc.

Auditing. CDR has pervious experience with the audit requirements o f the World Bank as they currently implement most of World Bank financed projects inLebanon. Ingeneral, the audits o f World Bank financed projects didnot identify any major accountability issues, however, over the last few years CDR has been systematically late in submitting these reports. As such, the external auditor's TOR should be preparedand submitted for the Bank's no objection, at least 10 months prior to the end of the project's fiscal year. Audit costs will not be financed bythe Grant.
The Project's financial statements will be audited by an independent auditor acceptable to the World Bank. The external audit report will encompass all project activities and will be in accordance with internationally accepted auditing standards. The annual audit report o f the project's accounts will include an opinion on the project's financial statements and the special account transactions. The project's auditor will also be required to give an opinion on whether expenditures reimbursed on the basis o f Statements o f Expenditures (SOEs) are eligible for World Bank financing and are reflected on the project's financial statements.
The following audit reports will be due under this project: IAudit Report IDue Date 1) Project Specific Financial Statements Annually by June 30 2) Special Opinions (ifspecifically required) 0 SOE Annuallv bv June 30 Special Account 1Annually by June 30
In addition to the audit reports, the auditor will prepare a management letter identifying any observations, comments and deficiencies, in the system and controls that the external independent auditor consider pertinent and will provide recommendations for their improvements. One combined management letter for all World Bank financed projects implementedby CDR is acceptable.
The proceeds o f the grant will be disbursed in accordance with the World Bank's disbursements guidelines as outlined in the Disbursement Handbook. Transaction based disbursement will be
13  used under this project. Accordingly, requests for payments from the grant account will be initiated through the use o f withdrawal applications (WAS) either for Direct Payments, Reimbursements, Replenishments to the Special Account (SA), or Issuance o f Special Commitments. All WASwill include appropriate supporting documentation including detailed SOEs for reimbursements and replenishments to the SA.
Authorized signatories, names and corresponding specimens o f their signatures will be submitted to the World Bank prior to the receipt o f the first replenishment application.
Retroactiveflnancing: Payments made to the grant recipient out o f its own resources before the date o f a grant agreement are normally not eligible for financing under the grant, except that withdrawals, in an aggregate amount not exceeding the equivalent o f US$ 1,000,000 million, may be made on account o f payments made for expenditures before that date but on or after January 19, 2007. Payments must be for expenditures that are eligible under the Grant Agreement. Procedures for procurement and the use o f consultants, and processing and clearances are subject to the World Bank's Procurement and Consultants Guidelines. Documentation requirements for expenditures claimed under retroactive financing are the same as those for disbursement against payments made after the Grant Agreement i s signed.
Statement of Expenditures (SOE): During implementation SOEs will be used for all expenditures relating to consulting services under consultant firms contracts costing less than US$100,000 equivalent each and under individual consultant contracts costing less than US$50,000 equivalent each. The supporting documentation will be maintained at CDR and will be made available for review by World Bank supervisionmissions uponrequest. Documentation relating to SOEs would be retained for up to one year from the date the World Bank receives the audit report for the fiscal year in which the last withdrawal application from the grant account was made.
Special Account: To facilitate project implementation and make timely payments, CDR will open a US$ SA at the Central Bank o f Lebanon. The authorized allocation will be US$750,000 with an initial deposit o f US$500,000. The SA will be managed and administered by the CDR who will also be responsible for submitting the withdrawal applications with appropriate supporting documentation for expenditures incurred. Deposits into andpayments from the SA to pay consultants and others will be made inaccordance with the provisions o f the grant agreement and the disbursement letter. Replenishments o f the SA would follow World Bank's procedures. The minimumvalue o f applications is 20% o f the amount advances to the designated account o f this project.
5. Safeguards
The project will finance only consultant and technical assistance services. Adverse environmental and social impacts during implementation o f the technical assistance activities are therefore very limited. The project has hence been classified as Category C, consistent with the World Bank Operational Policy 4.01. However, potential indirect social and environmental impacts o f the reforms supported by the project cannot be ignored and attention to such concerns will be carefully incorporated in the scope o f the relevant strategic advisory services supported by the project. Inparticular, the issue o f fuel oil storage will be closely examined inthe context
14  o f the fuel sourcing strategy, to avoid future dramatic environmental damage o f the scale o f the oil spill from the Jiyeh power plant's tanks, upon their destruction during the recent hostilities. Similarly, close attention in the scope o f the advisory services to the Ministryo f Energywill be given to identifying and minimizing the adverse impacts o f energy policies on the various stakeholders, with a particular concern for the most vulnerable stakeholders, such as the poor, when it comes to advising on an energy strategy, review o f tariff structures, and the overall restructuring o f the sector.

6. Sustainability and Risks
SustainabiZity. The design of the reforms has essentially been completed and a legal framework for the restructuring o f the sector exists. The focus therefore needs to be on implementation which is where progress has beenlacking inthe past. The combination o fthe current momentum for reforms inLebanon and the capacity that will be brought through the proposedproject should ensure sustainability o f the project.
Risks
(i) Delays in implementation: Based onpast project experience inLebanon, the proposed project could face implementation delays resulting from lack o f capacity This risk will be mitigated by the early establishment o f the Selection and Evaluation Committee and the increased capacity in financial management expertise in the CDR. Moreover, frequent communication between the Bank and the implementing agency, including the Higher Level Committee and the direct beneficiaries o f the assistance services, as well as regular Bank supervision missions will ensure support i s available when needed. Delay in implementation may also stem from difficulty to reach a political consensus at key decision junctures during the implementation o f the power sector strategy, EdL restructuring and internal reorganization. This risk is partly mitigated through close cooperation and sector dialogue with MOEW and other stake-holders in Lebanon. The project is also based on the Electricity Law, which was widely accepted by all parties and constitutes the platform for sector reforms. There is, however, a remaining risk of political interference ina fluid political environment, which cannot be mitigated inthe local context.
(ii)Inadequate$financing: About 35% ofthe estimated project total cost is expected to be financed by the GOL. The complementary financing from the GOL i s a testament o f its
15  commitment to the reform program. But it also represents a risk incase the Government finds it difficult to provide on time the funds needed, as faced with too many other calls on public finance for reconstruction, or should no other donor be able to fill the funding gap. To prevent any major setback inthe implementationof the technical assistance program proposed under the project due to failure o f obtaining full financing, the detailed design o f the program will be built insuch a way to clearly delineate activities and time frames for which financing is firm from the ones that remain conditional to a confirmation o f the availability o f complementary financing. Either way, clear priority will be given to the implementation o f the restructuring o f EdL, the major bottleneck to sector improvement. Also, the Bank has consulted with other donors, including AFD and EIBwho are bothkeen to support the sector.
(iii) Political and security risks: The current volatile political and security context in Lebanon represents a non-negligible risk to the adequate implementation o f the planned reforrn and investment programs inthe sector. This may have an impact on the lack o f interest by firms to bid on work in Lebanon, resulting in higher bid prices. Mitigation measures are the upfront indication that the consultant assignments are Bank financed with direct payment to service providers; and the limitedcommercial risk for the consultants resultingfrom the advisory nature o ftheir assignment.
E. ECONOMIC AND FISCAL JUSTIFICATION
Economic impact. With the support o f the technical assistance provided under the proposed project, improvement in sector investment planning should reduce sector investment needs and the long-term cost o f electricity. Improvement inEdL management and governance should also generate economic gains through a lower consumption o f production factors for power supply. The expected improvement in reliability will also have a positive economic impact by reducing the utilization o f non-economical individual power generators, and through the reduction of economic production lost due to power supply un-reliability. The economic impact o f the reduction o f power thefts i s difficult to evaluate, as the direct impact o f the reduction on welfare i s clearly negative, but the indirect impact o f the reduction o f subsidies may be socially beneficial, depending upon the utilization bythe Government o fthe savings on reduced subsidies to EdL.
Fiscal impact. The fiscal benefits o f the reforms can be measured in terms o f reduced need for Government subsidies. As part o f the Economic and Social Impact Assessment preparedby the World Bank, some scenarios were analyzed to assess the impact o f some measures, which included reduction in losses, better fuel management, and, eventually, a tariff increase in 2009. These scenarios also included expected efficiency gains from commercialization and private sector participation in the sector. All these scenarios indicated that government subsidies could be reduced over time with the understanding that these subsidieswould take several years to be fully eliminated. One scenario presenteda case where government subsidies to the power sector could eventually be phased out by the year 2012. This scenario assumed an annual reduction in technical and commercial losses, an oil price drop from the current level (US$50-60/barrel) to US$35/barrel by 2015, supply o f natural gas to key power plants (Zahrani and Bedawwi) at favorable prices, and a one-time tariff increase o f 25%. Inother words, the subsidieswill require several measures to be implemented simultaneously, and will take several years to be eliminated.

doc.repnme: Lebanon - Emergency Power Sector Reform Capacity Reinforcement Project
doc.abstracts: The objective of the Lebanon Emergency Power Sector Reform Capacity Reinforcement Project is to accelerate the implementation of reforms and restructuring of Lebanese Power Company (EdL) by enhancing the capacity in the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEOW), the Electricity utility (EdL) and a multi-Ministry Higher Level Committee (HLC) overseeing the reform process and in particular the restructuring of EdL, both in the short and the longer term. The project has three main components, with first being to support of the strengthening of MOEW to implement power sector policy reforms. This would include giving policy advice on key sector strategy issues, completing on going projects, and an establishment of a regulatory agency. The second project component is to provide support to the government of Lebanon for the restructuring of the EdL. The third component is to provide support to EdL to improve the operational and financial performance and the implementation of its restructuring. This would include developing a plan for procurement and efficiency, transmission and distribution reliability, help on financial issues and accounting, and the actual advisory of consultants for the restructuring.
